text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC for the past year the ongoing
crisis in the housing and credit markets
has set a gloomy backdrop for the 2008
presidential race fueling voters
anxieties about the economy and their
desire for change now the meltdown on
Wall Street threatens to deepen those
anxieties and provide John McCain and
Barack Obama with the campaign
equivalent of what Hillary Clinton once
described as that 3 a.m. phone call the
president's received it's not yet clear
who might benefit but increased
attention to economic trouble more
closely fits Obama's campaign strategy
as the Democratic candidates seeking to
replace an unpopular Republican
President Obama has always been better
positioned than mccain to capitalize on
desire for change and with voters
calling the economy their top priority
Obama has made the issue his central
theme but by choosing Sarah Palin is his
running mate John McCain managed to
shift attention back to cultural issues
over the past two weeks and that helped
him rise in the polls with the focus
back on the economy today McCain invoked
the crisis on Wall Street as an argument
for the reforms he says the Republican
ticket will bring to Washington with a
Republican in the White House now McCain
aides acknowledged that's not an easy
argument economic policy has never been
McCain specialty and to judge from her
interview on the subject with ABC's
Charlie Gibson last week it may not be
Palin's either but Obama hasn't yet
seized control of the economic debate
though polls show americans favored him
over mccain on the issue his advantage
lately has narrowed moreover polls show
a plurality of Americans consider Obama
a riskier choice than president than
John McCain Obama will now try to
convince voters the biggest risk lies in
McCain support for Bush's principal
economic policies most conspicuously on
taxes in particular he's seizing on
McCain's comment today that the
fundamentals of the economy are strong
McCain aides say that's a distortion I'm
John Harwood chief Washington
correspondent for CNBC
